title: Accidental Violation of a Core Policy
vignette: A chef tastes a finished dish and later learns it contained a substance strictly prohibited by their professional code of ethics. What must be done now that the breach is discovered?

options.text: A formal corrective action is required once informed of the violation.
No corrective action is needed since it was accidental and harmless.

title: Uncertainty About a Policy Violation
vignette: After a dinner party, a guest hears conflicting reports: the entrée 'might' have contained a prohibited ingredient or a permitted substitute. He cannot find out for certain. What should he do?

options.text: File a precautionary self-report about the potential violation, just in case.
Wait until there is certainty before taking any action.

title: Unable to Afford a Required Sanction
vignette: A member of a professional organization commits a violation for which the standard sanction is a fine they cannot afford.

options.text: Allow a delayed payment or a non-monetary alternative.
They must pay the fine promptly, even if it requires borrowing money.

title: Entering a Sensitive Area While Unqualified
vignette: A visitor enters the core operations wing of a private research lab without realising his access badge had expired. Days later the lapse comes to light. Does he owe a formal penalty?

options.text: A formal penalty is required once he is aware of the infraction.
No penalty is needed; his ignorance of the expired badge excuses the error.

title: Unintentional Violation Due to a Scheduling Error
vignette: Thinking a mandatory 24-hour professional moratorium began later, a person engages in a restricted activity. The official schedule shows the moratorium had already started. What is the corrective step?

options.text: He is subject to the standard corrective action for the violation.
Since he miscalculated, a formal apology suffices.

title: Multiple Violations in a Single Incident
vignette: A single action inadvertently violates two distinct rules in a code of conduct.

options.text: A separate penalty should be assessed for each rule violated.
A single penalty should cover the entire incident.

title: Violation Committed Before Becoming a Member
vignette: A newcomer engaged in a prohibited activity months before formally joining an organization that bans it. Must he address that earlier act now that he is a member?

options.text: No, the rules did not apply to him before he joined.
Yes, he must now undergo a corrective action for the past offense.

title: Intentional Violation with Later Remorse
vignette: Someone knowingly violates a core community standard—considered taboo—then experiences sincere remorse. What is required to make amends?

options.text: A formal penalty is still required, even though the act was intentional.
Sincere repentance and a public apology are sufficient.

title: Uncertainty About the Specific Violation
vignette: A person knows they violated a rule during a complex procedure, but is not sure which of two specific rules it was.

options.text: File a single, general report of non-compliance to cover the uncertainty.
Avoid any report until certainty about the specific violation is achieved.

title: Validity of a Corrective Action Using Borrowed Resources
vignette: A person is required to fund a remedial training session as a penalty. They borrow money from a friend to pay for it. The friend later objects to how the money was used. Is the completed remedial action still valid?

options.text: Yes, the action is valid. The source of the funds is a separate issue between the friends.
No, the penalty is invalid if paid for with contested funds. It must be redone with their own resources.

title: Equal Sanctions for All Members?
vignette: A question arises in a professional organization whether all members should face identical monetary or symbolic penalties for certain violations, regardless of seniority or status.

options.text: Yes, obligations and sanctions should be equal for all members.
No, sanctions can be adjusted based on factors like seniority or past record.

title: Partial Admission of a Violation
vignette: A member admits to one violation but conceals a second, related violation from the same incident.

options.text: They must confess fully to have the matter resolved.
Address the admitted violation and keep the rest private.

title: Funds for a Sanction are Misplaced and Found Late
vignette: Money set aside for a mandatory fine disappears and is found after the deadline for payment has passed. May those funds still be used to pay the fine?

options.text: Yes, use the funds to pay the fine, even though late.
The funds are considered invalid for that purpose; a new fine must be paid with different money.

title: Validity of a Corrective Action Using Revoked Resources
vignette: Someone borrows a specialized tool to perform a required corrective action. The owner retracts permission only after the action is complete. Does the action stand?

options.text: The action still counts; the user's intent was proper at the time.
It fails; it must be performed with resources that are properly secured.

title: Violation Committed by an Agent
vignette: A junior employee, following a manager's instructions, inadvertently violates a company policy.

options.text: The manager bears responsibility and faces the penalty.
The junior employee who performed the action must personally face the penalty.
